supporting_text: The NAP outlines a One Health approach that integrates human health, animal health, and environmental considerations.
The NAP includes specific strategies aimed at improving human health outcomes related to AMR.
The NAP addresses animal health through targeted actions to reduce AMR in veterinary practices.
The NAP includes actions focused on environmental health and its impact on AMR.
The NAP outlines strategies to address AMR in agriculture and food security.
The NAP specifies the establishment of a reporting mechanism to monitor progress annually.
The NAP sets specific targets with deadlines to measure progress in AMR control.
The NAP includes quantitative targets for reducing AMR prevalence and monitoring antimicrobial use.
The NAP outlines a budget allocation for implementing its strategies against AMR.
The NAP includes an assessment of future budget needs for various AMR activities.
The NAP establishes a multisectoral task force to coordinate AMR efforts across sectors.
The NAP includes actions to strengthen laws and regulations governing antimicrobial use.
The NAP emphasizes training and educational initiatives to raise awareness about AMR.
The NAP outlines public awareness campaigns to engage communities in combating AMR.
The NAP includes strategies for international collaboration with organizations like WHO and FAO.
The NAP includes actions for developing surveillance systems and data collection tools for AMR.
The NAP outlines strategies to enhance capacity for detecting and reporting new resistance.
The NAP includes specific prevention strategies focusing on sanitation and infection control.
The NAP incorporates international standards and guidelines for AMR control.
The NAP includes regulations for the distribution and prescription of antibiotics.
The NAP mandates the rational use of antibiotics through specific regulations.
The NAP includes participation in international research collaborations for new medicines and diagnostics.
